micro.title: Follow Your Waste
micro.tagline: The everyday story of your waste, as told by New York’s Strongest.

workers.name: Renee
workers.city: Take a trip to Governor’s Island and lay in the hammocks
workers.job: Some of us work in an office. My team uses computer technology to map out the best routes that Sanitation Workers should take when clearing the snow.

workers.name: Tuhina
workers.city: Have a picnic in Astoria Park with my friends
workers.job: I enjoy driving the mechanical broom. This helps keep the street clear from litter. I am doing my part to keep the city clean.

workers.name: Stephen
workers.city: Take a walk through Snug Harbor on my days off
workers.job: At my garage, I help with operations. I get to tow collection trucks if they break down and be the hero!

workers.name: Katia
workers.city: Ride the cyclone in Coney Island
workers.job: I like picking up corner litter baskets. Each litter basket weighs about 30 lbs. -- they don't call us New York’s Strongest for nothing!

workers.name: Tom
workers.city: Get lost in the cloisters up in Washington Heights
workers.job: I enjoy spreading salt on the roads during the winter. This helps the snow melt and allows first responders to do their jobs.

workers.name: Julian
workers.city: Get italian ices in Morris Park
workers.job: I play the drums in our department’s “Pipes and Drums” band! We march in various parades throughout the year including the Thanksgiving Day Parade.

dialog.not_trash: Oh no! This item can be recycled! Please drop the item into a different bin.
dialog.wrong_recycle: You have misplaced this recyclable item - an easy mistake to make. Try dropping the item into a different bin.
dialog.not_recycle: This piece of trash is not currently recyclable in NYC. Drop the item into a different bin.
dialog.correct_bin: You have placed this item in the correct bin! Now, learn from a NYC Sanitation Worker what happens next.

items.label: Aluminum foil
items.tooltip: Consider using reusable containers to store your food instead of aluminum foil.

items.label: Broken glass
items.tooltip: Double-bag broken glass to help protect you and your Sanitation Worker from injury.

items.label: Cardboard
items.tooltip: Flatten your cardboard boxes to easily tie up or put in a bag-- don’t forget the small stuff like pasta and soap boxes!

items.label: Potato chip bag
items.tooltip: This type of snack bag is usually made from different layers of materials, so they’re hard to recycle.

items.label: Laundry detergent
items.tooltip: Ignore the number on the bottle—NYC treats all rigid plastic the same way.

items.label: Food can
items.tooltip: These are made of steel or tin—not aluminum.

items.label: Glass bottle
items.tooltip: Glass is heavy and increases shipping weights, so product designers are using other options for food packaging.

items.label: Salsa glass jar
items.tooltip: Consider reusing glass jars for snack, crafts, and small items.

items.label: Milk carton
items.tooltip: Cartons are the most commonly misplaced item because they contain layers of both paper and plastic.

items.label: Newspaper
items.tooltip: Still getting your news the old-fashioned way? Reduce your waste by going digital!

items.label: Plastic bag
items.tooltip: In 2020, New York State banned most single-use plastic carryout bags from retailers.

items.label: Water bottle
items.tooltip: Nearly a million plastic beverage bottles are sold every minute around the world - make the switch to reusables!

items.label: Soda can
items.tooltip: A used aluminum can is recycled and back on the grocery shelf within just 60 days.

items.label: Toothpaste
items.tooltip: Not all bathroom items are recyclable—know before you throw!

paper.label: Garage
paper.caption: Hi, I am Sanitation Worker Tom from Manhattan. We start off our shift by clocking-in at our local garage then set out to pick up your household trash or recyclables.
paper.popup: Our Manhattan Spring Street garage located in western lower Manhattan is LEED-certified GOLD for its sustainable design features such as a green vegetated roof, use of recycled materials, harvesting of rainwater, energy and water efficiency, and low toxicity materials.

paper.label: Curbside Pickup
paper.caption: After leaving our Manhattan Spring Street garage, our Sanitation Workers pick up your cardboard and paper recycling from the sidewalk, and throw it into a DSNY collection truck.

paper.label: Marine Transfer Station
paper.caption: When our Sanitation Workers have completed their routes, they make their way to the 59th Street Manhattan transfer station.
paper.popup: Our logo hasn’t always looked the way it does today. It wasn’t until 1929 we became the Department of Sanitation we know today, and our logo became the most current caduceus: a winged staff with two serpents wrapped around it which represents good health.

paper.label: Weighing In
paper.caption: Before entering, the collection truck is weighed so we can determine the load’s tonnage. It is also scanned for radiation. If it tests positive, the truck is removed to ensure the protection of our Sanitation Workers.
paper.popup: When we say safety, service and sustainability, we really mean it! Since 2005, DSNY has used biodiesel fuel from soybean oil to fuel our fleet - DSNY boasts the cleanest fleet in the United States!

paper.label: Fish Bowl
paper.caption: Once inside the station, our Sanitation Worker is directed to available tipping bays.

paper.label: Tipping Bay
paper.caption: Then they are signaled to release their load of paper and cardboard trash directly onto a barge.

paper.label: Barge
paper.caption: The barge––full of NYC’s paper and cardboard recyclables––is guided by a tugboat from the Upper Bay through Kill Van Kull and to Arthur Kill Narrows to the Pratt Paper Mill in Staten Island.

paper.label: Paper Mill
paper.caption: When the barge arrives at the Pratt Industries Paper Mill, an operator steers a giant crane claw to scoop up paper recycling from the barge.

paper.label: The Pulper
paper.caption: Once at Pratt Paper Mill, the paper and cardboard recycling is first dumped into a pit and then fed into a Pulper. In the pulper, the paper is blended with water to create a pulp. This pulp passes through screens to remove contaminants.

paper.label: The Press
paper.caption: Then it is pressed, and ultimately dried and made into a large roll of recycled paper.

paper.label: The Winder
paper.caption: These huge rolls of recycled paper––which weigh 25 tons each–– are transported by a mechanized system controlled by a Mill Worker to the “Winder.”

paper.label: Storage
paper.caption: There, the recycled paper is cut down into smaller rolls, which are then transported by a forklift driver to a storage area.

paper.label: Corrugator
paper.caption: This recycled paper is ready to be distributed to a corrugator, where the rolls of paper are made into sheets of cardboard and then cut and folded into boxes.

paper.label: Quality Control
paper.caption: Mill workers examine the packets of cardboard boxes on the assembly line for quality control, and if they are happy with the standard then the recycled cardboard is distributed for use across NYC.

paper.label: Pizza Boxes
paper.caption: One big recipient of our recycled cardboard is our City’s pizzerias. Next time you’re about to bite into some tasty pizza, remember that pizza box could have been recycled from NY’s paper.

landfill.label: Garage
landfill.caption: Hi, I am Sanitation Worker Tuhina from Queens. We start off our shift by clocking-in at our local garage then set out to pick up your household trash or recyclables.
landfill.popup: Our current Queens West 1 garage was a former horse barn!

landfill.label: Curbside Pickup
landfill.caption: Once trash has been collected from the sidewalk, our Sanitation Workers make their way to the North Shore Marine Transfer Station.
landfill.popup: Our 2006 Solid Waste Management Plan eliminated 60 million miles of truck travel per year by dramatically reducing the number of truck trips.

landfill.label: Weighing In
landfill.caption: Before entering, the collection truck is weighed so we can determine the load’s tonnage. It is also scanned for radiation. If it tests positive, the truck is removed to ensure the protection of our Sanitation Workers.

landfill.label: Tipping Floor
landfill.caption: After weighing, a DSNY employee will be on the tipping floor to direct truck drivers to available tipping bays.

landfill.label: Loading Floor
landfill.caption: Trash from the DSNY truck will land on the loading floor located below the elevated tipping bay. Two front-end loaders push the trash into an available container, where it is then compressed by an excavator.

landfill.label: Lidding Floor
landfill.caption: Once the container is full, Sanitation Workers on the lidding floor seal the container.

landfill.label: Loading the Barge
landfill.caption: From here on, the container is the responsibility of a private contractor, who loads it onto a barge with a crane.

landfill.label: Barge-to-rail
landfill.caption: The barge––and containers full of trash––is guided by a tugboat to a container terminal, where it is off-loaded and placed on a train.

landfill.label: Landfill
landfill.caption: Finally, the train leaves and the containers of waste are either taken to a waste-to-energy facility to make electricity or dumped at landfill.
landfill.popup: In the United States, landfills are the third largest contributor of methane gas which is 34 times the greenhouse effect of carbon dioxide. Want to help combat the effect of climate change? Avoid the trash bin and try to reduce, reuse, or recycle!

metal.label: The Garage
metal.caption: Hi, I am Sanitation Worker Julian from the Bronx. We start off our shift by clocking-in at our local garage then set out to pick up your household trash or recyclables.

metal.label: Curbside Pickup
metal.caption: MGP––your metal, glass, plastic and carton recycling––is picked up by my fellow Sanitation Workers, and thrown into a DSNY collection truck.

metal.label: Marine Transfer Station
metal.caption: After completing our collection route, our Sanitation Workers head to Sims Hunts Point where your recyclables are put on a barge.

metal.label: Sims
metal.caption: The barge is guided by a tugboat to the Sims Sunset Park Material Recovery Facility (MRF).

metal.label: The Claw
metal.caption: When the barge arrives at the Sims Material Recovery Facility in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, an operator steers a giant crane claw to scoop up your MGP recyclables from the barge to the tipping floor.

metal.label: The Tipping Floor
metal.caption: In addition to the barge carrying recyclables, a DSNY collection truck arrives, and they too unload our City’s recycling into huge piles on the tipping floor.

metal.label: Sorting
metal.caption: From the tipping floor, the recycling is pushed into the sorting system by a front end loader. Alternatively––depending what equipment is available––your recyclables are picked up and dropped into the sorting system by a giant crane, known as an excavator.

metal.label: The Liberator
metal.caption: At this point, the recyclables enter the sorting system and first pass through a slow-speed shredder, known as the liberator, that rips open your clear recycling bags.

metal.label: Magnets
metal.caption: The recycling is passed under a large spinning magnet that collects ferrous metals, or magnetic materials. Later, an eddy current (a reverse magnet) repels any non-ferrous metals, such as aluminum.

metal.label: Trommel Screen
metal.caption: The ferrous metals, or magnetic materials, go through a trommel screen. As the trommel spins, the smaller items––like cans––fall through these holes and are transported to their very own baler This machine compresses materials into square bales. Unlike the smaller metal items, bulky metals are not baled, and get loaded onto a barge that goes to a scrap metal facility.

metal.label: Quality Control
metal.caption: The quality control step gives a final look at items that have been sorted. The quality control team is not exactly sorting the remainders, rather cleaning up what has already been sorted, or removing any remaining residue or trash from the recyclables.

metal.label: Railcar
metal.caption: By now, all materials are separated. Stacks of rectangular bales of crushed non-ferrous metal leave the facility on trucks; the bales of magnetic metals are placed into rail cars by a giant crane claw.

metal.label: Finished product
metal.caption: Finally, the rail cars, containing magnetic, ferrous metals, float across the Upper Bay, starting from the area near Owl’s Head Wastewater treatment plant, meet up with a rail line in New Jersey where they are taken to a plant for further processing.

glass.label: The Garage
glass.caption: Hi, I am Sanitation Worker Renee from Staten Island. We start off our shift by clocking-in at our local garage then set out to pick up your household trash or recyclables.

glass.label: Curbside Pickup
glass.caption: MGP––your metal, glass, plastic and carton recycling––is picked up by my fellow Sanitation Workers and thrown into a DSNY collection truck.

glass.label: Sims
glass.caption: After completing our collection route, we drive directly to the Sims Material Recovery Facility (MRF) in Jersey City to unload. The DSNY collection truck unloads your MGP recyclables onto the tipping floor, a giant room where recyclables are unloaded into massive piles.

glass.label: Sorting System
glass.caption: From the tipping floor, the recycling is pushed into the sorting system by a front end loader. Alternatively––depending what equipment is available––your recyclables are picked up and dropped into the sorting system by a giant crane, known as an excavator.

glass.label: The Liberator
glass.caption: At this point, the recyclables first pass through a slow-speed shredder, known as the liberator, that rips open your clear recycling bags.

glass.label: Disc Screens
glass.caption: After the liberator rips open recycling bags, all recyclables pass over rows of spinning metal rods called disc screens. While metal and plastic recyclables roll right over the spinning disc screens, the glass hits into the metal rods and breaks into small pieces. These pieces fall through openings between the disc screens and are caught by another conveyor belt below.

glass.label: Glass Plant
glass.caption: After the disc screens, the separated glass is loaded onto a barge and continues to a glass plant where it is sorted further into size and color.

glass.label: RGA
glass.caption: Finally, larger clear, brown, and green glass will be optically sorted and used to make new bottles. The smaller pieces of glass, or the pieces that are not clear, brown or green, are turned into Recycled Glass Aggregate (RGA) to be used for future construction projects.

plastic.label: The Garage
plastic.caption: Hi, I am Sanitation Worker Katia from Brooklyn.  We start off our shift by clocking-in at our local garage then set out to pick up your household trash or recyclables.

plastic.label: Curbside Pickup
plastic.caption: MGP––your metal, glass, plastic and carton recycling––is picked up by my fellow Sanitation Workers, and thrown into a DSNY collection truck.

plastic.label: Sims
plastic.caption: After completing our collection route, we head to the Sims Sunset Park Material Recovery Facility (MRF). The DSNY collection truck unloads your MGP recyclables onto the tipping floor, a giant room where recyclables are unloaded into massive piles.

plastic.label: Sorting System
plastic.caption: From the tipping floor, the recycling is pushed into the sorting system by a front end loader. Alternatively––depending what equipment is available––your recyclables are picked up and dropped into the sorting system by a giant crane, known as an excavator.

plastic.label: The Liberator
plastic.caption: At this point, the recyclables first pass through a slow-speed shredder, known as the liberator, that rips open your clear recycling bags.

plastic.label: Optical Scanners
plastic.caption: Your plastics move along conveyor belts that pass under Optical Scanners. When the scanner filters out nonrecyclable plastics, it cues an air jet at the end of the conveyor belt that shoots the item onto another conveyor.

plastic.label: Quality Control
plastic.caption: The quality control team cleans up what has already been sorted, removing any remaining residue or trash from the recyclables

plastic.label: New Products
plastic.caption: After being baled, plastics are loaded onto trucks and head out to be made into new products for sale.
